Subject: English Language
Content: Section A: Short-answer questions

Subject: English Language
Content: Instructions

Subject: English Language
Content: All questions in Section A relate to Text 1 in the Insert.

Subject: English Language
Content: Answer all questions in this section.

Subject: English Language
Content: In your responses, you are expected to:

Subject: English Language
Content: Demonstrate your ability to use relevant, descriptive and appropriate metalanguage.

Subject: English Language
Content: Demonstrate familiarity with the topics of Unit 3, 'Language variation and purpose', and the topics of Unit 4, 'Language variation and identity'.

Subject: English Language
Content: Text 1: Transcript of an interview between Sam Koslowski (K) and Dylan Alcott (A), from The Daily Aus podcast (21 September 2023). Alcott discusses his efforts to change perceptions around disability across sport, employment, healthcare and media representation.

Subject: English Language
Content: Identify one vocal effect in the text and describe its impact within the text. Use appropriate metalanguage and refer to line numbers in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Using an example, explain how Koslowski establishes Alcott's contributions to society. Use appropriate metalanguage and refer to line numbers in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Identify one example of a politeness strategy used in this interaction and justify how it influences the tenor between the participants. Use appropriate metalanguage and refer to line numbers in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Explain how changes in function throughout the text reflect aspects of the situational context. Use appropriate metalanguage, including Jakobson's functions of language, and refer to line numbers in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Analyse how Alcott and Koslowski's turn-taking strategies help to construct their individual identities as well as group membership in the wider community. Use appropriate metalanguage and refer to line numbers in your response.

Subject: English Language

Subject: English Language
Content: Text 2: Narragunnawali: Reconciliation in Education webpage from Reconciliation Australia, including an embedded YouTube clip transcript. The platform supports schools and early learning services to foster knowledge and pride in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander histories, cultures and contributions.

Subject: English Language
Content: Write an analytical commentary on the language features of Text 2.

Subject: English Language
Content: In your response, you should comment on the:

Subject: English Language
Content: Function(s), purpose(s) and intent(s) of the text.

Subject: English Language
Content: Situational and cultural context(s) influencing and affecting the text.

Subject: English Language
Content: Influence of register, tenor and audience.

Subject: English Language
Content: Relevant characteristics and features of language in the text.

Subject: English Language
Content: Refer to at least two subsystems of language in your analysis.

Subject: English Language
Content: Section C: Essay

Subject: English Language
Content: Instructions

Subject: English Language
Content: Section C requires a sustained expository response to one question: Question 7, Question 8 or Question 9.

Subject: English Language
Content: In your response, you are expected to:

Subject: English Language
Content: Demonstrate your ability to use relevant, descriptive and appropriate metalanguage.

Subject: English Language
Content: Demonstrate familiarity with the topics of Unit 3, 'Language variation and purpose', and the topics of Unit 4, 'Language variation and identity'.

Subject: English Language
Content: Refer to the stimulus material provided.

Subject: English Language
Content: 'Language defines our Australian identity, and its use is constantly changing.' Discuss, referring to at least two subsystems of language in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus A: When we say 'identity capital' about one person, it's similar to talking about the 'brand' or the 'mission' or the 'value' of a corporation ... But ... [i]dentity capital has a lot more to do with connections and relationships and community.
StimulusSource: Adapted from Jason Lalljee, '"Identity capital" is the key to getting your dream job and making friends in your 20s, according to Gen Z and millennials on TikTok', businessinsider.com, 11 February 2023

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus B: ... never lose sight of that other very important function* of language and that is to express your identity, whether that's personal identity or whether that's shared identity. So, the fact that [social media users] have to use writing of course means that they have to ... define the gang, if you like, they have to break out of the written standard. So there is, for example ... I mean, using the freedom of the net to convey their personalities, their personal identity, but also accommodating to their peers. [*not Jakobson's functions of language]
StimulusSource: Adapted from Kate Burridge, Big Ideas: Evolving English and the Role of Social Media, video, abc.net.au, 13 November 2011

Subject: English Language
Content: 'Our choice of variation in Australian English may both support and contradict our purposes in interactions with others.' Discuss, referring to at least two subsystems of language in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus A: Employee characteristics by generation — Baby boomers: optimistic, hierarchical culture, the chance to mentor others, respect. Gen X: innovative, strong communicators, autonomy. Millennials: tech-savvy, collaborative, training for new skills, flexibility. Gen Z: digitally fluent, practical, culturally competent employer, mentorship.
StimulusSource: Adapted from Kiran Zain Ashraf, 'Embracing generational diversity: The key to effective leadership', linkedin.com, 2 August 2023

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus B: You can safely bet your teens will continue to roll their eyes nearly every time you speak, but proper use of these new slang words and slang phrases will earn you at least grudging respect. Although I wouldn't go around speaking like a TikTok teen at the office ... that's just majorly cringe.
StimulusSource: Adapted from Robin Enan, 'Gen Z lingo explained: what every parent needs to know!', familyeducation.com, updated 1 August 2024

Subject: English Language
Content: 'Register and politeness often go hand in hand with the concept of social standing within contemporary Australian society.' To what extent is this true? Refer to at least two subsystems of language in your response.

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus A: There is long-standing research demonstrating the dangers of chatbots and their capacity to harm human creativity and critical thinking. This happens because humans seem to automatically trust bots and their outputs.
StimulusSource: Lucinda McKnight and Leon Furze, 'Australia has its first framework for AI use in schools - but we need to proceed with caution', theconversation.com, 4 December 2023

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus B: Survey results: 'Is political correctness ruining Australian society?' — Yes: 90%, No: 10%.
StimulusSource: Adapted from The Australian Seniors Series: Modern Manners Survey, seniors.com.au, 2017

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus C: Memes that infantilized older adults often portrayed them as immature and illiterate despite their age and emphasized their dependence on others. Memes that barbarized older adults portrayed them as being uncultured or having inferior cultural tastes ...
StimulusSource: Adapted from Si Yu Lee and Jasmon WT Hoh, 'A critical examination of ageism in memes and the role of meme factories', Sage Journals, Vol. 25, Issue 12, 7 October 2021

Subject: English Language
Content: Stimulus D: Politicians operate in an environment where their every word and action is scrutinized by the media and the public. This intense scrutiny can create an incentive to spin or distort the truth, as politicians may feel pressured to present themselves in the most favorable light or avoid potential controversies.
StimulusSource: T Grafton, 'What is the reason politicians use so much jargon and double-speak? Can you give some examples?', Quora, quora.com, 2023
